docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers recipes for spicy Indian dishes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HOT weather? Hot food. Just think about the countries that dote on dishes bolstered with chilies, curry mixtures and other fiery seasonings. Invariably, they are sultry places. A number of reasons have been suggested, including the fact that spicy foods make the body sweat and force people to consume more fluids, and spices like chilies are known to reduce bacterial growth, a bonus in places where refrigeration is not universal.

headline.main: Menu Drawn From India, Highlighted With Fiery Seasonings

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column describes how to prepare seafood tartars; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SEAFOOD tartars have become as familiar on restaurant menus as oysters or shrimp cocktail. Yet they are dishes people do not normally attempt at home. ''There's no reason why they shouldn't,'' said James O'Shea, owner of the West Street Grill in Litchfield. ''They are so easy.'' With their bright Asian spices, the tartars make vivid, elegant first courses and are fresh tasting and light. With his new chef, Joseph Morrison, Mr. O'Shea, who has always been passionate about seafood, has developed a series of dishes that sound complex because they use unfamiliar Asian seasonings but could not be simpler to prepare. Tuna is cut into small chunks and served with a soy lemon dressing mixed with kelp. ''The kelp releases carageenen and jells,'' said Mr. O'Shea, who grew up in Kenmare, in Ireland, where he used to gather it on the beaches. ''It gives a wonderful ocean brininess to the soy dipping sauce.''

headline.main: Seafood Tartars That Are Easy Enough to Make at Home

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill column gives recipes for sweets from Michael and Wendy London; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In general, the association of sweetness with romance works better for candy and greeting-card companies than it does for mortals. By nature, a sweet sensation is more fleeting than lasting, a leap into the ephemera. And without something dark and aggressive beneath its surface, sweetness quickly becomes cloying, as does romance, too. Mr. and Mrs. London, however, have created some sweet-sensation exceptions. The couple have made pastry and candy, bread, cakes and pies and even ice creams and chocolates for decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: FRESH chestnuts come into the market in late fall, imported from Italy. Yet chestnut woods once covered the eastern United States from southern Maine to southwestern Florida in one direction to eastern Arkansas in the other. By 1940, however, almost all the chestnut trees had disappeared. The historian Waverley Root said he believes that saplings imported from the Far East to Long Island in 1904 carried a fungus that ate into the bark of the chestnut trees. It proved fatal to the species, which had never been exposed to it before. No one realized until too late how deadly the fungus was, and the trees died.

headline.main: From Sauce to Side Dish, Chestnuts Aren't Just for Roasting

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN you watch a good chef get meat or fish ready for the outdoor grill, the first thing he or she does is put together a marinade. Sometimes it is nothing more than a mixture of olive oil, garlic and herbs. But it makes quite a difference to the taste of the food being cooked. Chicken goes well with lemon, olive oil and herbs, steak with garlic, olive oil and maybe a splash of red wine. The rich fatty meat of tuna and salmon are good with Oriental seasonings.

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers tips on pickling and preserving summer fruits and vegetables; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PICKLING and preserving have become recreational activities and are no longer necessities to prepare for the coming winter. Many people forgo these kitchen tasks entirely in favor of plucking jars off store shelves. But they will miss the satisfaction of opening a jar of crunchy sweet and sour homemade bread-and-butter pickles to serve with a tomato sandwich now, of spooning some spicy homemade chutney alongside roast duck in the fall or of spreading toast with winey plum conserve pulled from the pantry on Christmas Day.

headline.main: Capturing Summer in a Jar: The Fun of Pickling and Preserving

docs.lead_paragraph: FISH steaks on the grill have become almost as much of a summer tradition as hamburgers. Swordfish, salmon and tuna are especially popular because they cook without sticking and they take very well to the summer flavors of basil and thyme, tomato and sweet corn. It is important not to overcook the steaks or they will dry out. They retain enough heat to keep on cooking after they are taken off the grill, so it is better to remove them just before they have reached the desired degree of doneness. To eliminate strong, fishy flavors, tuna, swordfish, shark and marlin can be soaked in milk for a couple of hours before being cooked, a technique the French use for calf's liver.

headline.main: Grilling Steak, Whether It's Swordfish or Salmon

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column on some summer desserts using fresh cherries; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FRESH ripe cherries, one of the glories of early summer, should be selected with care. At their best, they are firm, glossy and have pliant green stems. They burst with juice and rich winey flavor. Although cherries are incomparable when nibbled fresh, a cook can intervene and transform a pound or two of cherries into an array of superb desserts. The following triple-header -- cake, ice cream and sauce -- takes its inspiration from the latest cherry crop.

headline.main: Tripling the Flavor of Cherries in Cake, Ice Cream and Sauce
